title: You've Won a Prize!
description: A classic prize-winning phishing email with obvious indicators.
context: You receive an unexpected email in your inbox claiming you've won a prize. You did not enter any contests recently.

content.subject: CONGRATULATIONS!!! You Have Won $10,000!!!
content.body_html:
Dear Valued Winner,

We are please to infrom you that your email adress has been selected as the WINNER of our International Email Lottery Program!

You have won the sum of $10,000.00 USD!!!

To claim your prize, please click the link below and provide your personal details and banking information for immediate transfer:

CLAIM YOUR PRIZE NOW!!!

WARNING: If you do not claim within 24 hours, your prize will be forfeited!

Regards,
Dr. James Morrison
International Lottery Commission

red_flags.label: Suspicious sender domain
red_flags.detail: The domain 'fr33-prizes.xyz' uses number substitution and a non-standard TLD — a clear sign of a fraudulent sender.

red_flags.label: Spelling and grammar errors
red_flags.detail: 'please' instead of 'pleased', 'infrom' instead of 'inform', 'adress' instead of 'address' — legitimate organizations proofread their communications.

red_flags.label: Artificial urgency
red_flags.detail: The 24-hour deadline pressures you to act without thinking. Scammers use urgency to bypass rational decision-making.

red_flags.label: Excessive punctuation and capitalization
red_flags.detail: Multiple exclamation marks, ALL CAPS, and dramatic formatting are classic phishing indicators.

red_flags.label: Requests personal and banking information
red_flags.detail: Legitimate organizations never ask for banking details via email links.

red_flags.label: Unsolicited prize notification
red_flags.detail: You cannot win a lottery you never entered. This is a social engineering tactic.

actions.label: Click the prize link
actions.feedback: Dangerous! This link leads to a fake website designed to steal your personal and financial information. Never click links in suspicious emails.

actions.label: Reply to ask for more details
actions.feedback: Replying confirms your email is active and may lead to further social engineering attempts. Do not engage with suspicious senders.

actions.label: Report as phishing and delete
actions.feedback: Correct! Reporting the email helps your email provider and IT team protect others. This is the safest response.

actions.label: Ignore and delete the email
actions.feedback: Good instinct! Deleting is safe, though reporting it as phishing is even better since it helps protect others.

learning_objectives: Identify suspicious sender domains and email addresses
Recognize spelling and grammar errors as phishing indicators
Understand how urgency is used to manipulate victims
Never provide personal or financial information via email links
Report phishing emails to help protect the community
